Package pulse.input

Class ExperimentalData

  • java.lang.Object
    • pulse.util.UpwardsNavigable
      • pulse.util.Accessible
        • pulse.util.PropertyHolder
          • pulse.HeatingCurve
            • pulse.input.ExperimentalData
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Describable, Saveable, SaveableCategory
    public class ExperimentalData
extends HeatingCurve
implements SaveableCategory

    An ExperimentalData object is essentially a HeatingCurve with adjustable fitting range and linked Metadata. It is used to store experimental data points loaded using one of the available CurveReaders. Any manipulation (e.g. truncation) of the data triggers an event associated with this ExperimentalData.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ExperimentalData

        public ExperimentalData()
        Constructor for ExperimentalData. This constructs a HeatingCurve using the no-argument constructor of the superclass, but it rejects the responsibility for the baseline, making its parent null.
        See Also:
        HeatingCurve

      • add

        public void add​(double time,
                double temperature)
        Adds time and temperature to the respective Lists.

        Note that the baselineAdjustedTemperature will be the same as the corresponding temperature, i.e. no baseline subtraction is performed. Upon completion, the count variable will be incremented.

        Parameters:
        time - the next time value
        temperature - the next temperature value

      • setFittingRange

        public void setFittingRange​(double a,
                            double b)
        Sets the new time range that will be used in the optimisation problem.
        Parameters:
        a - the lower time limit satisfying the a > b relation
        b - the upper time limit

        See Also:

      • crudeAverage

        public java.util.List<java.awt.geom.Point2D> crudeAverage​(int reductionFactor)
        Constructs a deliberately crude representation of this heating curve.

        This is done using a binning algorithm, which will group the time-temperature data associated with this ExperimentalData in count/reductionFactor - 1 bins, calculate the average value for time and temperature within each bin, and collect those values in a List<Point2D>. This is useful to cancel-out the effect of temperature outliers, e.g. when calculating the half-rise time.

        Parameters:
        reductionFactor - the factor, by which the number of points count will be reduced for this ExperimentalData.
        Returns:
        a List<Point2D>, representing the degraded ExperimentalData.
        See Also:
        halfRiseTime(), maxTemperature()

      • maxTemperature

        public double maxTemperature()
        Instead of returning the absolute maximum (which can be an outlier!) of the temperature, this overriden method calculates the (absolute) maximum of the degraded curve by calling crudeAverage using the default reduction factor 32.
        Overrides:
        maxTemperature in class HeatingCurve
        Returns:
        the absolute maximum of the baseline-adjusted temperature.

      • halfRiseTime

        public double halfRiseTime()
        Calculates the approximate half-rise time used for crude estimation of thermal diffusivity.

        This uses the crudeAverage method by applying the default reduction factor of 32. The calculation is based on finding the approximate value corresponding to the half-maximum of the temperature. The latter is calculated using the degraded heating curve. The index corresponding to the closest temperature value available in the degraded HeatingCurve is used to retrieve the half-rise time (which also has the same index).

        Returns:
        A double, representing the half-rise time (in seconds).

      • getMetadata

        public Metadata getMetadata()
        Retrieves the Metadata object for this ExperimentalData.
        Returns:
        the linked Metadata

      • setMetadata

        public void setMetadata​(Metadata metadata)
        Sets a new Metadata object for this ExperimentalData.

        The pulseWidth property recorded in Metadata will be used to set the time domain for the reverse problem solution. Whenever this property is changed in the metadata, a listener will ensure the fittingStartIndex and/or fittingEndIndex of this ExperimentalData are kept updated.

        Parameters:
        metadata - the new Metadata object

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object o)
        Overrides:
        equals in class HeatingCurve

      • getFittingStartIndex

        public int getFittingStartIndex()
        Returns the fitting start index, or the lower boundary of the time domain used in the solution of the reverse heat problem. This index can only point to a non-negative moment in time t >= 0.
        Returns:
        an integer, specifying the fitting start index.

      • isAcquisitionTimeSensible

        public boolean isAcquisitionTimeSensible()
        Checks if the acquisition time used to collect this ExperimentalData is sensible.

        The acquisition time is essentially the last element in the time List. By default, it is deemed sensible if that last element is less than 7.2*halfRiseTime.

        Returns:
        true if the acquisition time is below the truncation threshold, false otherwise.

      • getFittingEndIndex

        public int getFittingEndIndex()
        Returns the fitting end index, or the upper boundary of the time domain used in the solution of the reverse heat problem.
        Returns:
        an integer, specifying the fitting end index.

      • truncate

        public void truncate()
        Performs truncation of this ExperimentalData by cutting off the time and temperature data above a certain threshold.

        The threshold is calculated based on the halfRiseTime value and is set by default to 7.2*halfRiseTime. A DataEvent will be created and passed to the dataListeners (if any) with the DataEventType.TRUNCATED as argument.

        See Also:
        halfRiseTime(), DataEvent
